Title: How to Use Private key to encrypt a message and decrypt it using the same block's public key?
Headline: How to Use Private key to encrypt a message and decrypt it using the same block's public key?
Problem Description:
I am building a DApp where I want to add a message to all the blocks that shows that the blocks are created by the same company i.e my website and no one can replicate that message. So, I think the best way is to add a message to every block that is encrypted using the block's private key and anyone else can decrypt the message using the block's public key. Is this possible? If yes, then how? I am using web3.js and solidity.
P.S- I know the concept of digital signature it is pretty much the same...but in my case I don't want to verify the user who has signed the block but I just want to verify if the block is from my website or not.
Comments for Question:
1
            
        
        
            
                
                Nevertheless, use a signature. If you want to create a small signature, use a 256 bit elliptic curve (64 bytes). Any somewhat good encryption routine will take at least as many bytes of overhead. And, to be honest, any answer that does goes into creating such a "ciphertext" will go over your head and might not be secure.
                
                
– Maarten Bodewes
                
                Jul 12, 2022 at 14:09
            
        
    
    
        
            
            
        
        
            
                
                I’m voting to close this question because this is not about development, this is about Cryptography. But we've got a selection of questions that address that signature generation is different from encryption with the private key over there.
                
                
– Maarten Bodewes
                
                Jul 12, 2022 at 14:57
            
        
    
    
        
            
            
        
        
            
                
                Note that there is such a thing a signatures giving message recovering for e.g. RSA. However, you got to keep in mind that that will likely expand the message more than ECDSA, and the standard is outdated and barely used (see here for more info).
                
                
– Maarten Bodewes
                
                Jul 12, 2022 at 14:59

Title: How to implement Bitcoin address authentication protocol (BitID)?
Headline: How to implement Bitcoin address authentication protocol (BitID)?
Problem Description:
Bit-ID is an open protocol proposal allowing simple and secure authentication based on public key cryptography. I am trying to implement this protocol in dart using flutter and I am stuck at the HD derivation path.
HD structure

concatenate the little endian representation of index with the URI.
Compute the SHA256 hash of the result.
take first 128 bits of the hash and split it into four 32-bit numbers A, B, C, D (each in little endian notation)
Set highest bits of numbers A, B, C, D to 1.
Derive the HD node m/13’/A’/B’/C’/D’ according to BIP32.

In Digi-ID (an extension of the protocol in the Digibyte blockchain) integration guide, it gives an example for testing. I have successfully calculated the hash result but I am stuck at converting the hash to bip32 paths.
Testing
BIP39 seed: myth glimpse mystery abstract embark net faint hospital catch hint develop state
Callback URI: digiid://digiid.digibyteprojects.com/callback?x=c6140375e5bae71e
Index: 0
Hash result: 460ebbfd1df7410106d62d41f802f769bc00db825e9cf8c649cb069dec35e8fb
BIP32 path: m/2147483661/4256894534/2168583965/3241006598/3925279480
Digi-ID address: DJDAkjie6nrW6RpFZSTpNUXsZ9JE2x6p1o

Can someone explain the conversion from the hash to the BIP-32 paths? It would be helpful if the explanation is in dart.

Title: How to filter lazy minted NFTs of OpenSea through API?
Headline: How to filter lazy minted NFTs of OpenSea through API?
Problem Description:
OpenSea and Rarible NFT Marketplaces allows to lazy mint NFTs tokens. Those lazy minted NFT could be a potential threat because they can be minted in large quantities for free.
Is there a way to detect if NFT assets are lazy minted using OpenSea API?
By default OpenSea API returns both lazy minted NFT and those that are on-chain.
Is there a way to filter lazy minted one?
Fore example this API call retrieves an asset:
https://api.opensea.io/api/v1/asset/{asset_contract_address}/{token_id}/

There is a boolean property "is_presale": true in the response. Is this the one that indicates that the NFT is lazy minted?
{
  "id": 12345,
  "num_sales": 0,
  "background_color": null,
  "image_url": "https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/xxx",
  // ...
  "last_sale": null,
  "top_bid": null,
  "listing_date": null,
  "is_presale": true,// is this a flag that NFT is lazy minted???
  "transfer_fee_payment_token": null,
}

I've also noticed that lazy minted NFTs often contain a much longer token URI, for ex.:
0xabcd947276749ce646f68ac8c2484200abadbabe/1234567890278879774873980199088900019547633730998071615740870393857

whereas minted NFTs often have something like this:
0xabcd947276749ce646f68ac8c2484200abadbabe/12345

So I'm thinking maybe as an alternative, there is a way to know that an NFT is lazy minted by analyzing its tokenURI or smart contract?

Title: What's the role of a centralized back-end on a dApp?
Headline: What's the role of a centralized back-end on a dApp?
Problem Description:
I'm a bit puzzled on how a centralized back-end is integrated into the bigger picture of a back-end project, and googling has been of little help.
On a traditional CRUD back-end, it just receives requests from the front-end, normally queries a centralized database then returns the relevant data.
However, I am aware that a dApp doesn't necessarily need a back-end as the blockchain already acts as that.
So my question is basically, when is a centralized back-end needed or encouraged for a dApp?
As a follow-up, I'm also unsure on how the back-end is supposed to authenticate users. That is, is there a way to connect with Metamask and the likes to identify the user making requests?
A particular use-case I would like to explore is an NFT marketplace. What's the purpose of a back-end for something like that? I'm sure it'll be useful for saving user data not on the blockchain, but are blockchain-specific data also advisable to be store offchain?

Title: Metamask-mobile browser not working on server side sessions and exchange the session ids via cookies
Headline: Metamask-mobile browser not working on server side sessions and exchange the session ids via cookies
Problem Description:
The cookies functionality have been broken for the past releases. This bug is causing a lot of issues to the developer community and not allowing Dapps to work properly with MetaMask mobile. We can confirm that the android version of metamask-mobile browser seem to have a problem with websites that use server side sessions and exchange the session ids via cookies. It also affects websites developed with Ruby On Rails session handling.
For a reproducible test you can see the problem on https://matic.art

w3.eth.defaultAccount = session_conf['votersAddress']
if not args.no_sign:
    w3.geth.personal.unlockAccount(w3.eth.defaultAccount, session_conf['votersAddressPassword'])
    logger.info('Voters account successfully unlocked')

chirotonia = Contract(w3, session_conf['mainContract'])

voters = []
for voter in session_conf['voters']:
    voters.append(Voter(private_key=voter['private_key'], description=voter['description']))

for vote in session_conf['votes']:
    if args.vote and vote['name'] != args.vote:
        continue
    if vote['status'] != 'started':
        logger.warning('Skipping vote %s because not in status started (found %s)', vote['name'], vote['status'])
        continue
    txs = []
    pkeys = [v.public_key for v in voters[:vote['voters']]]
    logger.info('Inserting ballots for vote %s', vote['name'])
    for i, ballot in enumerate(vote['ballots']):
        voted_ballot = voters[i].ring_sign(pkeys, Voter.pack_vote_in_random32(bytes([ballot])))
        txs.append(chirotonia.vote(vote['name'], voted_ballot))
    gasSpent = 0
    for tx in txs:
        tx_rcpt = chirotonia.wait(tx)
        gasSpent += tx_rcpt.gasUsed
    logger.info("Gas spent %d", gasSpent)
    logger.info('Ballots for vote %s successfully inserted', vote['name'])
    vote['status'] = 'voted'


with open("./runs/%s.json" % session_name, "w") as session_file:
    json.dump(session_conf, session_file, indent=4)

logger.info("Configuration updated at ./runs/%s.json", session_name)

Title: Are payable functions susceptible to 'out of gas' errors?
Headline: Are payable functions susceptible to 'out of gas' errors?
Problem Description:
Im creating a contract with this intention of minting NFT's using the 'payable' functionality. In testing I have found that the contract correctly appends the payable fee to the remaining gas cost to perform the rest of the contracts functionality (i.e. normal contract interaction would cost .001 ether, I add a fee of 1 ether and now the function interaction costs 1.001 ether.
However my concern is in times of high latency if metamask does not correctly predict gas fees is it possible that my my contract will take the payable fee however not have enough gas to complete the minting process of the NFT? Meaning the customer would have spent their money but receive nothing in return?
Another follow-up question regarding this is that when I set a payable function I have to manually input the amount of ether to send. Is there a way to set up a payable function that metamask will automatically interpret and add the fee preventing the need to manually input a ether value and allowing the user to just click 'mint'?

1
            
        
        
            
                
                Most blockchain networks are public, so they are not really suitable for storing sensitive data. Plus I'd be very hesitant to store even encrypted sensitive data on a public blockchain - it's the same security risk as allowing read access to another database holding encrypted private data... What is your intention/goal for this approach or storing PPI related to NFT? Maybe there's a solution using a private blockchain network, or an offchain service storing the data accessible through some onchain authorization.

import brownie.network as network_

And, inside of a thread i'm doing this:
def addFileBlockChain(add, testnet, filename, text):
  import brownie.network as network_

  if network_.is_connected():
    network_.disconnect()
  
  network_.connect(testnet)

  if testnet == "kovan":
    dev = network_.accounts.add(os.getenv('PRIVATE_KEY_K'))
  elif testnet == "goerli":
    dev = network_.accounts.add(os.getenv('PRIVATE_KEY_G'))
  else:
    dev = network_.accounts.add(os.getenv('PRIVATE_KEY_R'))

 contract = TxtFileShare.at(add)
 contract.addFile(filename, text, {'from': dev})

But, only 1 thread works, the others raise exceptions like this:

Using brownie we can't connect to various networks simultaneously? If yes, how (using import on python)?

Title: GCP PubSub many-to-many (fanout) implementation
Headline: GCP PubSub many-to-many (fanout) implementation
Problem Description:
I'm using PubSub for a custom semi-centralised blockchain network where I have each node in the network publish and subscribe to transactions and blocks added to the chain.
My goal is to have a fanout approach where each node must receive the message even if one acknowledges it first. My understanding is that I will need a different subscription for each of the nodes in order to achieve the above.
When I looked into the limitations, it seems like there's a maximum number of subscriptions per project which is 10,000.
How can I achieve a the above for more than that number? Or is PubSub not a possible option for my implementation?
If not, do you recommend a specific alternative?
I'm aware of p2p methods used in other networks, but the issue there is speed of delivery which makes the network extremely slow with growth. In my case I do not care or even prefer the PubSub system to be centralised, so the "decentralised" argument here is not valid.
I thought of simply having my nodes "not acknowledging" messages, but that can be abused by anyone who touches the distributed code, and I'm not sure what other issues will arise from that.
Should I maybe have multiple projects, each with similar configs, and randomly select some of the nodes that will be listening to one and publishing to another to "relay" messages?
Any feedback, guidance, direction would be greatly appreciated.
Comments for Question:
3
            
        
        
            
                
                If your limit is the number of subscription per project, I agree, create several projects. However, you can have a topic in one project and be reachable from another one. Similarly, you can have a subscription in a project and the topic in another project. There is no relay to create for that. However, pulling subscription is optimized, but it's still HTTP network traffic and if you have large volume of data, you will have similar network issues. Not sure that this design resolve that issue..
                
                
– guillaume blaquiere
                                
                
                May 22, 2022 at 20:16
            
        
    
    
        
            
            
        
        
            
                
                On one hand the number of subscriptions seems to be a soft-limit based on documentation, but on the other hand I'm thinking about the network quotas as well. I'm not 100% I understand clearly those limits mentioned here: cloud.google.com/pubsub/quotas#quotas (In general my message size is about 15-20KB that needs to be published to all subscriptions/nodes). Worst case I might introduce local messaging queues?
                
                
– Waelmas
                
                May 23, 2022 at 8:31
            
        
    
    
        
            
                    1
            
        
        
            
                
                I agree with @guillaumeblaquiere's comment. And regarding the local messaging queues, this will give more durable message delivery mechanism and will probably eliminate the network issues since you will not be needing to connect over a network in sending/receiving messages.
                
                
– Scott B
                
                May 24, 2022 at 1:23
                        
                            
                        
            
        
    
    
        
            
            
        
        
            
                
                Do all of the subscriptions need to be on the same topic? If so, you will also run up against the 10,000 subscriptions per topic limit.
                
                
– Kamal Aboul-Hosn
                                
                
                May 29, 2022 at 15:14

I'm considering moving to AWS SQS for production as it seems their limits are much higher. Otherwise a self-hosted solution.

Title: How do I create a valid TRX address?
Headline: How do I create a valid TRX address?
Problem Description:
How can I create a valid address?
code:
random_string = "T"+str(''.join(random.choices("ABCDEFGHJKLMNPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijkmnopqrstuvwxyz123456789", k = 33)))

def address_to_hex(base58addr):
    addrchecksum = base58.b58decode(base58addr).hex()
    address = addrchecksum[0:42]
    checksum = hashlib.sha256(hashlib.sha256(bytes.fromhex(address)).digest()).digest()[0:4].hex()
    if checksum != addrchecksum[42:]:
        raise ValueError("Invalid checksum")
    return address

print(address_to_hex(random_string))

Title: How to securely implement a deadpool in a PoW blockchain?
Headline: How to securely implement a deadpool in a PoW blockchain?
Problem Description:
Imagine you have a blockchain where the Proof of Work scheme is integer factorization. There is an opcode that takes two integers N,M where it returns true if M∉{0,1,N} and N mod M ≡ 0. Now, suppose we want a number factored, say Mg. It could be a Cunningham number, a brilliant number or any other number where there is an interest in knowing its factorization.
We can create a transaction where the locking script for the funds of the transaction is this opcode with Mg as the first input. This way the unlocking script is just any non-trivial factor of Mg. This would allow anyone on the blockchain to claim the reward for this factorization.
Two issues: miner-in-the-middle attack and reorganization attack.
Miner-in-the-Middle Attack: The miner who receives a transaction with the unlocking script will be able to see the factor in plain sight and replace that transaction with one where the funds are sent to their wallets instead of the solver's.
Reorganization Attack: If the value of the blockchain's coin is high there is also an incentive to attack the block in which a solver transaction was mined by re-solving that block with a replaced transaction accrediting themselves(the attacker) and attempting to create a longer chain from this new block.
So,the question becomes, how can solutions be submitted safely in this blockchain? Is it possible to do it in two transactions, or are three transactions required? Is there any blockchain that has solved this problem already?
Thank you.
Note 1: I choose tags that are the most related to this topic. It also seems like the bitcoin stack exchange is strictly for bitcoin.
Note 2: This question was posted on the cryptography stack exchange to get ideas on cryptographic mechanisms that might help implement this. It is also posted here because there is a blockchain tag and there may be implementation details and solutions which may be achieved with the current opcode set plus this new opcode. It seems this community stack exchange is the most suited for the latter.
